questions.question_text: What is primary purpose of using the Cisco SD-WAN vManage Certificate Management API?

discussion.content: Correct answer is C

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/sd-wan/217426-understand-the-web-certificate-for-vmana.html

Answer is C
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/sd-wan/217426-understand-the-web-certificate-for-vmana.html

It is C, 
A - vManage cert mgmt API is not used to deploy vManage
B - no such feature
D - Cert Mgmt API does not contact Ent CA on its own

choices.B: to report an issue to Cisco TAC

discussion.content:
https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/Command_Reference/Command_Reference/vManage_REST_APIs/Real-Time_Monitoring_APIs/Users

Answer is: users?

The correct answer is "users?" as you can see here:

https://developer.cisco.com/docs/sdwan/#!device-realtime-monitoring/users
API call for real-time monitoring of users logged in to the device.

Device Users
Display the users currently logged in to the device.

GET https://{vmanage-ip-address}/dataservice/device/users?deviceId=deviceId

the correct syntax is - https://{vmanage-ip-address}/dataservice/device/users?deviceId=deviceId
so the correct answer is - users?
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/sdwan/#!device-realtime-monitoring/users

It's 'users?'.
'interfaces?' returns configured interfaces... answer is 100% incorrect
Wow this answer is ridiculous. Wth?

choices.D: They block until a response is returned from the servers.
choices.B: They make your application less portable, so asynchronous calls are preferred.
choices.C: They can add perceived latency to your application if data is not received.
choices.A: They can be used only with certain programming languages.
choices.E: They do not block while waiting for the API to be processed.

discussion.content: answer is CD

Selected Answer: CD
Synchronous calls will add latency whether or not data is received.

Selected Answer: CD
CD for the win !

Selected Answer: CD
Vote C & D
Answer is C and D

Selected Answer: CD
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/packaged-contact-center/#!synchronous-vs-asynchronous-writes/synchronous-vs-asynchronous-writes
CD is the answer
CD for sure

questions.question_text: What are two characteristics of synchronous calls to APIs? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Correct answer is B&D
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/sdwan/#!device-template/attach-device-template

Selected Answer: BD
I guess it is TaskID instead of ProcessID. But DeviceID does not make sense since you can launch multiple asynchronous API for the same device.

Selected Answer: BD
processID is returned after the post, then you use it to lookup device action status.

comments.content: PUT would replace current attached devices with just that one device, it should be POST

choices.D: POST call to initiate the attach action
choices.C: PUT call to initiate the attach action
choices.E: GET call to initiate the attach action
choices.A: ג€monitor device action statusג€ GET API request with the device ID to display the status of the attach action
choices.B: ג€monitor device action statusג€ GET API request with the process ID to display the status of the attach action
